title: Travel Shaving Cup/Bowl/Mug
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Not a remix, but certainly inspired by this snap-lid shaving cup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:709619

Mine separates the knob from the lid with a threads so all parts (save for the mug loop) should be printable without any support.

I made this back in October 2016, but I somehow forgot to post it.

comments.text: I really like the design. I have been using this quite a bit, as I have been spending more time in a hotel than my own house lately. My only problem is the pegs keep snapping off the lid. I printed the lid twice and two of the pegs snapped off within the first day each time. Wonder if it would be better if the support ring was moved out towards the edge to take some of the pressure off the pegs, or even a screw top lid?

Important Make sure there is clearance between the altimeter and all thread, otherwise you will short it. Ask me how I know this.... A nylon washer or two beneath the mounting holes of the altimeter will give you enough clearance to be safe, and still fit in the tube. - Edit: This is no longer an issue with update published on 5/16/17

Run a single piece of M6 all-thread through the bay, with a forged eye nut threaded to each end. This will hold the bulkheads in place, as well as give you a safe spot to attach shock cords to. I plan on drilling a hole in the all-thread to put a cotter pin through to prevent the eye nut from backing off the thread during flight.

This includes a mount for an Atlas Metrum EasyMini dual deploy altimiter.
https://altusmetrum.org/EasyMini/

This uses two 1000mah 3.7V batteries, wired in series to bring the voltage to 7.4V. This will power the flight computer as well as ignite the ematches for deployment.
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-nano-tech-1000mah-1s-15c-round-cell.html

Total weight of the print (Including 4.5g for the Easy Mini and 20gx2 for the batteries) is x grams.

title: R55 Handbrake cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Handbrake cap for an R55 (Clubman) MINI Cooper. Will most likely fit any Gen 2 MINI, still needs a little work, but works fine for now.

123D Designer and a camera

This is a freeform re-model of the handbrake cap for an R55 (Clubman) MINI Cooper. In all actuality, will most likely fit any 2nd gen MINI, but haven't tried yet. It fits loose, so I may edit and make the clips .5 - 1 MM shorter. I have already broken one of the clips on this version, and will be tweaking the reinforcements.

I designed this by taking top / front / side photos of our broken one, looking at a non-broken one online for the clips, and a (good) bit of trial and error. AutoCAD 123D Designer was used. Source and STL are both included. Please re-mix and help me fix!

author: AdamLWolf

description.text:
After having 2 VTX RPSMA connections ripped off, i designed this. This is specifically designed for the above VTX.

Enjoy

This is a little clip-on filament guide for the Folgertech FT-5 but it will work for any printer with 2020 aluminum extrusion rails. Simply snap it on and pass your filament through the guide! There are models with holes parallel and perpendicular to the extrusion. If your printer is not very precise, you may want to scale up this model 1%-2% to ensure it snaps on correctly, but make sure that it clips tightly enough to not slide.

print_settings.Notes:: Print one and measure the inner and outer size, add the missing values as a tolerance and reprint to make them fit perfectly to your printer.

description.text:
I tried to print several available bearings from Thingiverse, none of them where perfect to fit my needs, so i made a customizable bearing in OpenScad that can be used/customized to fit most 3D printers and can replace default LM8UU or LM10UU or even larger ones. When the design is opened with customizer you specify your needs, like height, outside-, inside diameter and more. I even added the option to add secure rings to the design.

A tolerance setting was added which can be used to compensate for specific printers or different kind of filaments. for example when I'm using my FFCP printer with ABS I need to add an additional tolerance of 0.5 mm to make it work (due to shrinking of the object during cool down).

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used ABS and added a tolerance of 0.5mm to compensate for the shrinking during the cool down process when using my Flashforge Creator Pro. PLA or PET would do fine too i guess.

As an infill you can use any percentage from 10% to solid, i personally used 50%.
My printing speed was 50mm/sec and around 1hour to printout 4 pieces.

Print one and measure the inner and outer size, add the missing values as a tolerance and reprint to make them fit perfectly to your printer.

comments.text:
You are right in telling that all what is published here in term of LM replacement is not OK except the ones I made using Igus filament which beat ALL what is published here :)
I just made TR8 nuts that works fine, no play no backlash just needs a bit more torque compared to brass. This is normal, known and acceptable.

title: Silicone Sock mold for new e3dv6 Volcano
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1845407, I want to give credit to the inspiration design.
This is a rework of a mold to create a silicone sock for a new 3D cartridge style volcano hotend.
I used 2 methods to make the actual socks. I used 2 part high temperature silicone -- Mold Max 60 for prototypes. It cures fairly quickly -- I let it cure for 24 hours and was able to test molds quickly enough. I suggest make several molds as air pockets tend to get trapped and generally 1/3 to 1/2 of the molds I made were failures. The 2nd, more permanent set I made were from regular 1 part RTV high temp silicone. This takes much longer to cure -- I gave it 5 days. Again, half of the molds failed because of air pockets but the other were perfect.

I basically poured some mixture into the assembled mold, then insert the insert piece and let it force out the excess. Then use a syringe to backfill from the other side. It's very hard to fill the mold entirely with a syringe, I found it to be impossible for the silicone I was using.

title: DJI Phantom Zenmuse H3-3D Gimbal SJCAM adapter

description.text:
Zenmuse H3-3D Gimbal SJCAM adapter (based on SJ5000+)
The cable can be made by removing the USB connector from gopro hero3 USB cable supplied with the gimbal and soldering the SJCAM/XIAOMI micro USB to AV cable instead (2nd photo).
Adapter should be secured with 2 screws and a bit of hot glue in the corners.
The thin wall inside is the support, to be removed after print.
TURN THE PART UPSIDE DOWN and align the part or tweak you slicer so that the first layer of the middle plate is printed diagonally for best results.

UPDATE added the schematics of the cable.
On sjcam/xiaomi AV cable there are two black ground wires, but the placement does not matter since they are connected together inside the usb plug.

title: Monoprice Select Mini pi camera mounting bracket

description.text:
My Monoprice Select Mini has the y-axis smooth bars bolted directly to the bed, so there are a couple of tiny screw holes in the corner of the bed, perfect for mounting my camera to for an Octoprint setup. If you have the older Select Mini, you can still use this by just swapping out the y axis bracket screws for longer ones to go through this bracket, through the holes, and through the y axis bracket. 12mm should do it.

I wanted the camera offset at an angle to get a better view of the print, so I designed this little diagonal mounting bracket. Angled at 22.5 degrees, the screw holes are inset so it's easy to mount with an M3 bolt and nut.

I used the front of the camera case from this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:403712/

And the back of the camera case and the 40mm links from this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247590

With a few more M3 bolts and nuts, it's all put together. Solid, so it doesn't shake as the bed moves.

title: Base for Mostly Printed 3D Printer MP3DP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm very happy with my MP3DP. The Mostly Printed 3D printer is mostly stiff, but I thought it would be better if there was a strong base, to hold the corners. This makes the XY plane really square. I used the original STL and dxf files to create this.

I cut it using my MPCNC, which I am also quite happy with.

My base was cut from 3/4 inch "red oak" plywood. I cut the relief for the 4 corners and two side plastic pieces at a depth of 3mm.

If you want to cut this with EstlCAM, then use the "Exploded" version. If you want to edit this in a CAD program, use the normal one.

comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Acrylic is notoriously brittle, and prone to stress fractures. It will even crack around screw holes if fasteners are over-tightened.
However, for only $150 it's an extremely inexpensive entry-level printer, producing the same quality prints as printers 4 times the cost. Best of all, in order to make it twice as strong, you only need to print a half dozen mods, which is a great exercise in tweaking the machine while costing nearly nothing.
I see no problem with any of it. Just don't accidentally sit on the damned thing.
I doubt the paper helps with strength, I just hate shiny shit reflecting light in my eyes while I'm working. If I wanted pretty I would have bought roses.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Yes, it is cheap but for a little more you get an Al or steel frame that you can improve with your own parts and get quite a decent printer. It is what I did with my Geeetech Al Prusa.

Complete new World Trade Center complex. All created by me, except for the transportation hub (Turner Construction Company). Includes the base (with memorial), 1 wtc, 2 wtc, 3 wtc, 4 wtc, 7 wtc, wtc museum, and wtc performing arts center. All of which put in their near-exact locations, as currently planned (which will probably change because they've changed it multiple times). I put a lot of research into each planned building however since a lot of them aren't built yet and people care more about 1 wtc, there was a lack of info for them, as a result, the dimensions for each little crook and cranny on the buildings aren't 100% accurate. However, I assure this is a great model that puts light on each aspect of the WTC, not just 1 wtc, and most of the dimensions (including ALL overall widths and heights for each building) are correct. This was also designed with slight modifications to 2 wtc so no supports are needed but if you feel worried about the performing arts center, supports may be ideal.
This is a model of the book character named Kipper the Dog and now you can print it on your 3D printer. Get yours now or download the files

I designed this to slide over the edge of a file holder.

I originally drew this up in SketchUp (v1) but recently have switched to Fusion 360 which is amazing.

The new design is 100% parametric. I've included the Fusion 360 file too if you would like to modify your label dimensions.

I also added a fillet to the recess for the label, that way the edge will print cleanly on the over hang.

I have a brother QL-570 label maker that came with a roll of Small Address labels (2.4" x 1.1"). My actual measurements of a label were 62mm x 29mm. In v2 I sized the recess in the label holder to fit those labels plus a 1mm margin and a 1 mm fillet.

In v2 I also adjusted for the thickness of the plywood in my unit, which is 5.2mm. I added an extra 0.1 mm to have some buffer.

I've noticed that the labels from my label printer don't seem to like the shiny layered surface of the PLA. I put a thin layer of glue stick glue down before applying the first label and that solved that problem.

Which one to print:

Label_Holder_Parametric_v2.stl is the file that you most likely want to print

Label_Holder_Parametric_v2.f2d is included if you'd like to edit the design
Label_Holder_v1.stl is included just in case you like the first version better

title: i3 A8 Badass DiggityDank MK8 Carriage

description.text:
If you own an Anet i3 clone, throw aside your 3 aluminum bearing blocks, 6 snap rings, 14 screws, belt clamp, & metal carriage bracket, because this carriage fully integrates what had been 28 separate pieces of hardware into a mere 4. Also suitable for other i3 clones.
This carriage is smaller & lighter than most i3 clone carriages, meaning less mass and less vibration.
This carriage also places the extruder tip 20mm closer to the bottom linear bearing, instantly giving you a 220x220x260 build area, and the sash latch & front clip give instant access to printer head removal.
This carriage also includes optional integrated support for the Badass DiggityDank MK8 X-Carriage Cable Chain.

Notice Print a necessary nozzle before installing carriage.The blower position puts the duct 3.5mm left shifted from the extruder tip. Simply load the .stl file of any preferred Anet A8 nozzle into TinkerCAD & mirror the image. It's the same offset as the A8, only in the opposite direction.

History: Simhopp spit out the idea of a unified carriage concept, & I ran with it, basically remixing the thing all to Hell.
I removed the inner bracket inserts to allow for a wider variety of motors, I widened the front clip to better support the blower, I replaced the blower hook with a screw tab. I moved the sash latch further back to not hit the blower housing. I mirrored the sash latch so the tension pulley knob wouldn't be in the way. I removed excess material from carriage. I pulled the brackets out by 4mm so the fan wouldn't hit the X-stop, adding more X-axis travel via a 20mm trigger foot. I raised the bracket by 20mm, placing the tip 5mm from the bottom bearing, giving an additional 20mm of vertical build space (you may need to update firmware if you have an integrated height limit). I finally added a cable chain clip option. My cable chain found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2090751

Thanks to Simhopp's initial design idea. Visit his designs: http://www.thingiverse.com/Simhopp/designs

Printer:

Anet A8 i3 kit clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40 for bracket, 20 for everything else.

Notes:

Supports are necessary for crisp lines under overhangs, they provide the best fit.
Print the blower duct at lower temp for best bridging.
I'd use a raft for ABS, but not PLA.

comments.text: Testing this on a Folgertech i3 with the clear frame. So for I havent had any issues with a 30 min test print. Have you noticed and warping on the underside of the carriage due to heat rising from the heatblock?
comments.author: drkness01

comments.text: No. The tiny element inside the heat block will never radiate enough heat to melt or warp anything outside of the block. Filament needs to physically touch the block or tip to melt... The glass transition of filament is significantly lower, but again that's only if the filament is physically touching the throat without a fan cooling it. Air is a great insulator, which rapidly dissipates heat. Hold a thermometer 5 or 10mm from the heat block, you'll see that the heat doesn't rise like that. It's not an 800C flame from a burning candle. It's a very small & contained heat source. Even printing nylon or PC, it won't get hot enough to affect anything outside of it.

Who claimed this is "necessary"? This is just another optional Thingiverse modification which may improve the performance & quality for certain printers.
I've explained at length within the description. It isn't about "problems it solves", it's about providing an alternative design which works better for many people. Print it out, experiment with it. If you don't like it either reinstall your original carriage, redesign this one to suit your own purpose, or go blow. All my designs are public domain, tear this shit up if you want, redesign it to your own classifications.

title: Latching Broom Handle Clamp Hanger  Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a broom or tool holder that snaps shut to secure circular handles. This particular instance was designed to fit around a 21mm diameter broom handle, but it works with similar diameter handles. It could feasibly be scaled for much larger things as well, however the screw holes and hinge pins will need to be adjusted as well. This thing prints in place in one piece with no supports (see print settings for specifics). I used nails that were 1.7mm in diameter as the hinge pins. Includes two counter-sunk holes to fit most small screws, as always, pre-drill your wall for best results.

Here is a video of this particular one in action: https://gfycat.com/ImmenseBeneficialLabradorretriever

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm or smaller layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If you print this at larger than .2mm layer height, your slicer may not leave a gap between the print-in-place hinges. I printed at a .2mm layer height and my slicer skipped exactly one layer for the gap and the hinges printed perfectly with no supports or fuss. I did have to run a razor blade down the center gap, however, to separate the gripping claws as the first layer fused a little. Mine was printed in ABS

i have fun.

This is a three piece wand inspired by Harry Potter, but can be used for cosplay, SCA, and other geeky goodness.

A rectangular pin holds the handle together with the tip (please read the post-printing instructions for that part!).

The wand tip is 167mm, so please make sure your printer can handle printing something that tall!

The total dimensions of the wand are about 9.75" by 1/2" wide at the handle.

My first attempt at printing wands had the tip in two pieces, but it just wasn't as sturdy as I wanted. So, I came up with this design.

I have other handles that fit with the same tip, and am working on additional modles. Take a look at my other wands!

Thanks for looking, and have a magical day!

Printer:

Monoprice Ultimate

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

at least 80%

Notes:

I print these using a wood/pla hybrid, which is pretty brittle stuff, so I use a temp. of 215. Colder can clog the nozzle. And an infill of at least 80% for stability in the wands.
My printer has a heated bed, making the raft unnecessary, but if your print isn't sticking, feel free to use one.

Step 1: Glue

Once you're done printing, you'll need to glue the pieces together. The pin will fight pretty snugly, and it's supposed to. I use diamond glaze for this. It's a resin adhesive that works really well on several types of surfaces, but is water based and easy to clean up.

drop a little glue in the hole, add the pin, press together, and let dry standing up! Filament spools work well for this. Allow plenty of time for the glue to dry before moving forward! Step 2: Stain

This part's totally optional, but it makes the wands look really nifty.
You'll need stain and a paint brush. I use a gel stain from the craft store. It's nice and thick so it's easy to work with.

Using the brush, paint long, even strokes along half of the wand. Start with either the tip, or the handle, but don't stain the whole thing all at once or you won't be able to hold onto it or let it dry without making a huge mess. Allow time to dry. The long strokes from the brush will dry to make it look like it's got wood grain! Once dry, stain the other half. Let dry standing upright. Step 3: Varnish

Another optional step, but using the same method as the staining, use a water based varnish to give the wand a gloss coat. I use a polyurethane varnish for this. Thick, water based, easy to clean up.

Feel free to experiment with different kinds of stain, different coats of varnish or stain, etc.

Step 4: Make magic

You know what to do here. Enjoy!

title: AR-15 Compliant Fin Grip Mk I

description.text:
The fin on the back of the grip is designed to prevent a pistol style grasp, and the webbing of the hand falls above the trigger. The fin is offset slightly to the left to allow for a more comfortable grip. There is a thumbrest designed to be comfortable for the user and keep the webbing of the hand above the trigger. I apologize to all the left-handed folk out there, I'll get an update out for you as soon as possible.

The only prototype I have completed so far is a PLA mockup at low infill. I'll soon print another prototype with some minor changes in Taulman's nylon 910. The next model will have a larger, more comfortable palm rest, more ergonomic thumbshelf, and slightly flatter grip angle.

This is still a work in progress. This grip may not be compliant in all configurations. Use at your own risk the same way you would a kydex grip wrap or similar fin grip. Because of this, I have uploaded a .ipt file for anyone who wishes to modify or improve the grip. I will post a .step file soon as well.

Qidi Tech 1

The orange prototype seen in the pictures was printed in PLA at 0.2mm and 25% infill. I recommend using ABS or Nylon for better strength and impact absorption. For ABS I recommend scaling to 110% to combat shrinkage. Print with the base flat on the bed.

This is a E3D V6 mount for the MPCNC machine by Allted.
It mounts on the original tool mount using two of the #8 bolts and lock-nuts.
Mount it in the 2nd to last holes from the bottom, if you want more Z height you can edit it to move the hot end up farther but you will need a slimmer endstop mount.
Also dont mount it in the lowest set of holes as it robs Z height and induces Z wobble.

Hardware:
2x M3 bolts
2x M3 nuts

The clamp piece only fits one way so if it doesnt fit swap it.
The bolts that thread into a nut in the nut trap. If the nuts spins use a screwdriver to hold it. However the bolts dont need to be crazy tight, as it clamps very well.

title: Anet A6 (and A8) Glass Bed Clips (3mm glass)

description.text:
I was fed up of the warped aluminum hotbed of my printer so I went to a glass store and had a piece of 3mm glass cut to 220mm x 220mm, brought it home and cut the corners to allow access to the leveling screws. After using it for 24 hours with the paper clips to hold it down I realized that the pressure from the clips was preventing the glass from remaining perfectly flat so I searched for some clips, but did not find anything that fit the Anet A6 the way I wanted it to.

When I found PodgyPie's clips (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1719319) I liked the design, but they were too big and did not work with the Anet A6 tighter tolerances (frame vs bed) so I made them fit, beveled the edges to allow the back left clip to miss the mainboard screws and reduced the thickness of the tops. I then decided to split the front left clip since homing the extruder would crash the fan duct into the clip. With the clip split in 2 for the home corner it allows you to position them out of the way.

To note: I have found it more convenient to only use 1 front home clip on the front edge of the bed to avoid clip crash when homing the printer.

I labelled the clips even though they are all the same other than the home clips, just because I could :-)

If you have any comments or suggestions let me know.

EDIT Jan. 12th, 2017 - I changed the settings to reflect use of support. Seems I missed that when I created the thing.

EDIT JAN 13th, 2017 - I have refined and reduced the gap in the clips by 0.35mm and they are a tight fit, they hold well. The issue I have is the ones I printed are in PLA and when the bed heats up, after a few prints using the clips, they open up and become loose.
So if you want these to last you will have to print them in ABS or something that has high heat tolerance.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

Whatever makes you happy

Notes:

For support, be sure to use Lines at 20%. Used Cura.

These clips are designed with tolerances of 100th of a millimeter. You need to be careful when you clean up the supports because if you take out more material than the support then you will reduce the clip's power to hold the glass.
Made in Tinkercad

title: Compression style Printrbot Simple replacement collar spacer

description.text:
Since I have been using a flexable steel cable (vinyl coated), I have noticed that getting it too tight and it would slip worse. I attributed it to the OEM vinyl tube flexing/compressing, letting the cable slip. This is my attempt at the solution. It uses a nut I found from an old CB channel changer. The nut size is 12mm. Not sure what the hole size/thread of the nut is. I wrapped and superglueed 220Grit wet/dry sand paper to the cylinders surface. Fingers crossed. I did drill/ream the collar our with a 5mm drill bit after printing.
Yes, once the collar is installed on the shaft, I tightened the nut untill it was tight.

description.text:
I've been working on my Tronxy X3 and came up with a simple 40mm fan mount after noticing how hot the stepper drivers were getting. The Tronxy X & Y axis are a little draggy and need extra power to keep from missing micro steps. After bumping up the drive power, the prints were coming out much better but the heat build up on the drivers was concerning me. This cooling fan mounts on the controller board next to the front panel. It uses the existing board hardware and a couple of 3mm screws and nuts to mount the fan.

I added in a version that points the fan downwards at 10 degrees.

This is an incomplete work in progress that I figured I would share and see what people thought. It consists of 4 files that can be combined in 123d or similar software to make a complete tunnel. The measurements should enable it to work with a certain name brand ferret tunnel.

Tunnel format is as follows......

1st. Tube Mouth
2nd Tunnel Part (add multiples to achieve length)
3rd Tunnel Blank
4th Tunnel Finial

Also needed is a grommet to keep the tunnels together (as with the name brand tunnels). Again this is a project for a later date.

Note I have not printed this yet but the measurements were taken very carefully.
If you print this, please tell me what you think and how it worked for you.

I will be designing 45 and 90 degree turns as well as T's and four-ways.

description.text: Pipette rack using 8mm-diameter tubes (e.g. sterile 5mL serological pipettes) as a frame.

Setup
  1. Print out two angle brackets for the base, and four screw brackets for the frame
  2. Connect two vertical rods to two horizontal rods for the frame, using the screw brackets. These will rest on the pipette handle and barrel respectively. The screwable hole (with bit taken out of it) is for the vertical rods to stop them slipping from gravity.
  3. Insert hex-head 4mm bolts into the screwable holes, and tighten with a 4mm nut
  4. Place the vertical rods into the angled holes in the angle brackets
  5. Connect another horizontal rod through the angle brackets for additional stability

description.text:
An K8200/3Drag enclosure for the RepRap Full Graphic Smart Controller.

It was my design goal to achieve a solution with as few components as possible and preferably without screws. In the design process, my goals were achieved, but the solution was difficult to print and did not have the strength I wanted.
I ended up with a design using only two screws, press fits and is easy to print ...

The hole on the left side is for adjusting display contrast and the X button is reset.

Hope you like it :-)

Besides the printed parts you will need two hex cap M3x12mm screws (DIN 4762). Self threading plastic screws can be used instead of M3 screws.

Print the following and assemble as shown on the picture:

  • 1x Enclosure
  • 2x Clips
  • 1x Knob
  • Optionally 2x Insulator for M3 screws.

I used PTEG plastic for the enclosure shown on the picture, as it has very little warping. I think most filament types will work as long as it has some springiness.

comments.author: VerbalT

comments.text: The input should be around 5amps. If the fuse does blow it wont start a fire, that's what its there to prevent. Should the power supply short it will draw more power through the fuse causing the fuse to blow, shutting off power before a fire can start. I use a 5 amp fuse on mine and it works fine.

description.text:
OpenSCAD rhombic dodecahedron tile with holes for magnets.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhombic_dodecahedron

You'll need to print a total of 12 tiles, and 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). That's 48 magnets in total. I bought mine on eBay in bulk and used superglue to secure them in the tiles.

See the User Defined Variables section of the OpenSCAD script for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). Or just use the pre-built STL file (holes for magnets are 6.5mm diameter and 2.5mm depth, designed to accommodate 6mm diameter magnets with 2mm depth).

Not familiar with OpenSCAD? It is easy to obtain and use! Download it here: http://www.openscad.org. After installation, open up the OpenSCAD file for this thing and hit F6 to render (or use the menu options up top). File->Export as STL and take it to your slicer!

These are also on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

title: Logitech G25 G27 G920 Shifter Handle Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple Logitech Shifter handle adapter. The idea here was to let me fit a common thread shifter knob from ebay nicely onto the G25 shifter I have.

For the demonstration, I used a BMX foot peg as a handle ($10 for 2 pegs... bargain). It feels great and I'm happy with the fit.

The thread for the BMX Peg was a Imperial 3/8th UNF bolt... In the pictures I initially did a 10mm bolt but obviously I had guessed the thread size wrong as I'd printed it before getting a knob/handle to test on it.

So this file is a 3/8th UNF bolt. If you need a different thread size, let me know and I'll update a version for it. As far as I understand however the standard is 3/8th for a shift knob. Let me know if its not in the comments...

Check out more of my work in oznzsimracing.com forums

http://oznzsimracing.com/forums/m/16887284/viewthread/29285694-3d-modellingprinting-sketchup-fusion360

and more of my electronics stuff... here.

http://oznzsimracing.com/forums/m/16887284/viewthread/23526371-ramjetx-simrig-other-stuff

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

No

Supports:

No

0.2mm worked fine

10% - 20%

Notes:

Depending on the shaft length, you might want to make it more solid with wall thickness and infill.

The higher it prints, the more weight sits on the spring return in the shifter and it feels a little softer on return to center strength. No big deal.

If your using it as a sequential or handbrake lever. You can now put a lengthened shifter handle on it and make it feel more authentic.

description.text:
So... on the back of the T3PA pedals, there is an unused mounting hole behind the Throttle pedal...?

Perfect for mounting up a vibration motor I'd hot glued into a 25mm conduit saddle mount clip hey?

It's a mod I'd done with an arduino to feel vibration when I'd locked up wheels with ABS or sliding due to excessive drifting skillz... etc.

Anywho... You'll see the way I'd mounted the vibration motor I'd stripped out of an old gamepad. I used a 5mm bolt and nut to clamp this to the bracket and two 3mm pk screws into the pedal base.

Keep the 3mm screws into the pedal base fairly short.. no more than about 5mm deep?

title: Raspberry Pi 2 mount for Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a bracket to mount a Raspberry Pi 2 case to the side of a Duplicator i3 Plus. It was designed with the dimensions of the Canakit case but should fit most Pi cases. The dimensions of the Canakit case are 62.7mm x 93.7mm x 31.4 mm and there is about 1 mm of tolerance in the actual bracket itself. Larger cases should fit. Smaller cases may require slight modification so the clips hold it in place.

On the right side of the Z axis gantry there are holes for mounting a z-axis limit switch, but they aren't used. Use M3 cap screws and nuts to attach the bracket and insert the case with the USB ports facing up.

Here's a list of parts from McMaster Carr:

This is a button to save fingers on the Anet A8 Extruder Motor

Update 3/7/17:
Thanks to Dayne427 's awesome Redhood variant print (go check it out!) I've edited the back portion to include room for ears so that the helmet is easier to wear. I'm not sure what orientation Dayne427 printed the back portion but I included a pic of the Cura settings and orientation that I think would work best.

Note 3/5/17:
I kinda just realized that I really didn't explain how the mask and the back were supposed to attach. There are two vertical posts in the interior of the the back part. Those were originally meant as posts that one end of an elastic band could wrap around. The band is then supposed to feed out of the slots on the back of the helmet. The other end I originally planed to have Velcro that stuck to the mask. The interior of the mask on each side near the ear there should be a rectangular recess for the Velcro strip. This way the helmet should be able to slip onto the head pretty easily (theoretically).

Make sure to check out awesome makes by JimmyTime and Danye427!

Update 1/20/17:
Hey! V4 is here. So some tune up (strap anchor has some fillets now, the forehead area's thickness is definitely better [not crazy thick]!) I've also sliced it a new way that I think should make things easier. Removed the old files cuz things were getting confusing and cluttered but if you want those for whatever reason just message me!

Update 1/16/17:
Full Crossbones head gear! Mask + Back Cap (minus strap). Broke down pieces to fit my plate but message me if you'd like me to split some other way. Upload half, figure you can mirror on your own (right?) Still trying to find time to print, but please share if you beat me to the punch!

Update 1/14/17:
-Hey ya'll. V2 > V1. Touched up the temple area. Most important got rid of most of the super thin and sharp areas. Tossed in some fillets...more to come!

1/12/17:
-Crossbones Mask as seen in Captain America: Civil War.
-Seen some others on-line that were kinda eh so I thought I'd give it a go. I used screenshots from the Kabam app game Marvel Contest of Champions.
-Personally haven't split and printed yet (if anyone beats me to it Good Luck!)
-2nd half (back part) should be coming soon!

print_settings.Notes:: I narrowed the mount for a snug fit on the bed -- so do NOT over-extrude, if you do the mount point will likely be too tight. remixed_from.author: Marksman79
remixed_from.title: Lulzbot Mini Camera Mount (Y-mounted) for time lapse video

description.text:
Logitech C270 webcam mount for the Lulzbot Mini. Having the camera move with the bed means the print appears stationary in timelapse videos, like this:
https://youtu.be/uUmA5bCMpU4

I started with the STL from thing 1602952 by Marksman79, cleaned up the geometry a bit, and narrowed the mounting point for a tighter fit. Then I integrated the C270 mount from thing 1228521 by luc_e, setting it at the proper angle to point the C270 at the center of the Mini's bed.

The camera mount itself is a direct replica of the original C270 mount, so the same axle and screw removed from the C270 can be used with this mount.

NOTE: This is for the Lulzbot Mini 1.03 and prior bed design (silver bed). The Mini 1.04 bed design (black bed) is slightly different and this design may not fit (not tested, as I don't have a Mini 1.04 to check).

Sketchup file included for anyone that wants to tinker further!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

65%

Notes:

The only area that may need support is the mount holes. I was using PETG and it drooped a bit without supports. With something that bridges better, you may get away without supports.

I narrowed the mount for a snug fit on the bed -- so do NOT over-extrude, if you do the mount point will likely be too tight. Since this is a lengthy print, I recommend using your slicer to "cut" the model and test-print just the top portion (the mount) to test fit on your bed before printing the entire model.

Imported STL models into Sketchup, which (as usual) makes a very difficult-to-edit model. Spent a lot of time and was able to clean up most of the problems, at least to the point where the sketchup file is reasonably editable -- although there are still some surfaces that should be coplanar but are not.

author: Crazyace63

description.text:
I have found the setting up of the bed to ensure levelness has been a real pain, so inspired by fotomas's modification for the Y Idler Bracket on the ormerod 2 and johneato's Y belt tensioning device for the ormerod 1 and richokarl and his Y rod fix July 2015 I produced this enhancement.
This modification allows the front Y rod to be raised or lowered in order to fix any rod twist. I have also removed the countersink holes that join the Y Idle bracket to the Y axis end plate and replaced them with straight holes

All items are printed at the same time but I have included the scad file so that you can create individual stl files if you wish.

This is a parametric version of the proximal phalange used for Robohand.  
I tried to make a Robohand scaled to adult size, and found a couple of areas I thought could be improved.  First, I did not like that all of the fingers were equal in length - very unlike a normal hand.  Second, the uniform length was too short - smaller than a pinky finger.  Third, there was no ability to control the hole sizes, leading to some problems with holes that were too big or too small.  Fourth, there was no ability to control the fit between parts, leading to too much lateral motion in some joints.  
This version allows you to tweak the settings to make the fingers custom to your needs.  It allows you to set the scale factor to match the other Robohand parts.  You can then set the length of the phalange, the size of the holes for the knuckles, the size of the hole for the bungies, the size of the hole for the drive string, and the thickness of the tabs to tune the fit with other parts.  There is also a support option to make it a bit easier to get a good print.  
I have made a first test print of these - scaled to the actual finger lengths of the person for whom I am making the hand.  They appear to work properly, but the hand is not complete and more testing is needed.  For that reason, I am going to call this a work in progress for now.  
NOTE:  I have no medical training whatsoever, and make no warrantee of any sort regarding this part.  I am providing it in the hopes that it will be helpful for others.  If, however, you intend to use it, seek appropriate medical attention from a trained physician.

Open the .scad file and customize values in the PARAMETERS section.  
Start by setting the scale factor to match the scaling used for any other Robohand parts.  The sample .stl files I included used a 1.3 scale.  Once the scale is set, set the length of the phalange.  If desired, adjust the hole sizes (in mm) for different size screws, different size bungie cords, or different size strings.  If desired, adjust the thickness of the phalange to make a tighter or looser fit into the other parts.  
There is also a Support parameter that can be set to true or false.  If true, the bottom of the print will be squared off a bit to make an easier print (because of less initial overhang).  The parts will then need a little filing or sanding to round them back out.  I found this well worthwhile since it made the parts print much more cleanly.  I tried conventional support settings, and that did not work as well as this solution.  If you don't want/need that extra support, just set the value to false.  
Once the values are set, use OpenScad to compile the object.  Be forewarned that this takes a long time to compile.  I do it on a laptop that is a few years old, and it takes about 4 hours per finger.  Although that is a long time, I think it is worth it to have customized parts.  It should be less time on a newer, more powerful system.  You need a fairly recent version of OpenScad because of the dependence of this object on the Minkowski function that had bugs in some older versions.  Once the file compiles, export it as an stl.  You will probably need to use Netfabb to repair the stl.  Then slice and print the repaired stl.

comments.text: An observation: When we created Robohand and kept all the fingers the same length it had to do with the anatomy of how a normal hand functions. When you close your own hand around an object do all your fingers stay the same length when the hand is closed? Regards Beth

title: Precise Z positioning of camera by using spot laser

description.text:
The Video camera plugin in Mach3 is extremely powerful tool - you can position the tool precisely and quickly over the desired location of the detail. By knowing the distance between the camera cross hair and the spindle centre we can quickly switch between these two positions by using simple scripts (attached to the project). The camera is fixed to the CNC spindle head and if using objective with long focal length it's possible to get decent image magnification from distances of 100-200mm to the object. By using the camera it's possible to position the head with precision better than 0.025 over specific detail features, find the centre of holes, edges, etc. In two words: very useful for all everybody who uses CNC (attached are the camera scripts and the screen for Mach3).

There is one major problem with the camera - it's very difficult to make it exactly perpendicular to the surface so by moving the camera up/down on Z axis the image crosshair can shift which is compromising the positioning precision. I played a lot to adjust the camera and with the time I achieved quite good vertical alignment but it's a slow process.

At the end I found one elegant solution of the problem - if a laser is mounted on 45 angle to the camera (on 70-100mm distance away) and if the laser spot is hitting the center of cross hair when focused on the surface then we can guarantee that the camera distance to the surface is always constant and the perpendicularity of the camera to surface is not so important. See attached a picture describing how the method works and a short video showing how the laser and camera perform together:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=50kZa79QLbA

There is one benefit of using the laser - now we can measure distances in Z direction with precision around 0.05..0.1mm. If we focus the camera/laser on one surface and if we set this Z level to zero then if moving the camera/laser to a new position(and focusing the laser spot on the new position) we can see the new Z level.

The design of the laser mount allows to tilt the laser in two directions to get the spot exactly under the camera crosshair (or slightly on one side to avoid covering from both lines of the crosshair) . See video how laser tilting works:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vujrtNEpsyM

Once the laser spot is on the exact place we can fix the position with the screws.

For the camera I use Microsoft LifeCam Cinema with replaced objective. This particular camera is very suitable for embedding into designs because of its cylindrical shape:

  • https://www.amazon.com/Microsoft-LifeCam-Cinema-720p-Webcam/dp/B009CPC6QA

    • 30mm megapixel objective (with infrared filter!) from https://www.vision-dimension.com/en/lenses/mini-lenses-s-mount/megapixel-mini-lenses/35mm-5mp-megapixel-board-lens-irc-bl-5m3525mp12irc/397
  • lense holder: https://www.vision-dimension.com/en/lenses/lens-accessories/lensholder/objektivhalterung-lensholder-m12x0-5-18/388

The process of removing the LifeCm lenses could be seen on :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oBrsLO9uH0c

Adding the lense holder will require some extra skills but is not that difficult.

The laser module could be used from some cheap laser pointer but I found that it's very fragile and difficult to focus. So I used some better grade laser module from TME (LC-LMD-650-05-01-A)

http://www.tme.eu/en/details/lc-lmd-650-05-01-a/laser-modules/laser-components/

Added 220 Ohm in serial to keep the current 13-15mA from 5V which will increase the laser life substantially and also make the laser dot not so bright. By screwing the lense we set the focus - the laser spot to be as small as possible when camera focused on surface and positioned in crosshair.

description.text: This is an enclosure that I built out of 2 IKEA LACK tables, some Velcro, and hot glue. I got the idea from this Instructable: http://www.instructables.com/id/3d-Printer-Enclosure-from-Upcycled-Furniture/ . I designed this with the intent of having more room for the printer than the one in the instructable though.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.125-.25

Infill:

100

Notes:

I have added a picture of the assembly in SOLIDWORKS, as well as built so that you can see how it is assembled. Velcro is used at the top so that the corners are adjustable for when the acrylic is put in place. Any screws in place are only there for extra support. I was in a hurry, so I put hot glue down, but I would recommend something like gorilla glue for the filament holder on top. For the power supply, I had to unscrew the leg some, and then wedge the plate it was mounted on between the table and the leg. If you have a different printer then the power supply will probably be different, so I would just mount it any way you want on the bottom, that way you don't have to worry about it overheating inside the enclosure. The case I printed out was specifically for a raspberry pi 3 with a 5 inch touch screen by 52pi.

The only things that really need to be bought are the raspberry pi, LACK tables, Acrylic siding (optional), and the 5 inch screen.

LACK Table (Need 2): http://tinyurl.com/z4zwef8
Raspberry Pi 3: http://tinyurl.com/joslhc2
5 inch touch screen: http://tinyurl.com/hf2leoa
Acrylic Siding (Need 4): http://tinyurl.com/hqmgjle

I plan on making a kind of hinge piece later on when I actually have the rest of the Plexiglas.

description.text: Simple Case for Adafruit Minty Boost USB Charger. http://www.adafruit.com/products/14

Peanut butter without jelly, chocolate without peanut butter, me without chocolate ... some things are just not cool. Like a pencil without an eraser. What's the point? (Answer: the sharp bit on the opposite side of where the eraser should be.)

This Thing solves the problem of my large collection of eraser-less IKEA pencils.

In addition to the printout, you will need:

  • A trip to IKEA to buy meatballs. Keep the pencil.
  • Eraser vinyl strips (white cylinder of eraser-material)

The model is a 20mm long cylinder with a 10mm-long circular cut from one end, and a 10mm-long hexagonal (pencil-cross-section-shaped) cut from the other end. I recommend re-creating the model in your software, as it will take a few tries with a new printer to get the tolerances on the diameters just right so that the eraser and pencil fit in tightly.

comments.text: I don't want to use it in the water. 'Watertight' is another term for 'manifold'. This link explains it: http://airwolf3d.com/wiki/manifolded-edges-how-to-check-if-your-model-is-watertight-and-ready-to-3d-print/

comments.text: that's really cool.  Can you tell us more about it?  How did you create it?  I saw a similar "art" moon on kickstarter for hundreds of dollars but it wasn't really the moon.  Did you use some lunar topo database?  Just thinking to would be cool to do it in reverse so it looks like a smooth ball until lit up (lithophane style).  My kid's rooms have ceiling fans with a single light on the bottom.  With a dimmer it would make an awesome night light.
comments.author: JustForFun

comments.text: Hi there! I created this not using a topological map, but rather the moon's "color" (even though it's pretty much black and white. The darker areas, or Mare, are printed in thicker layers of plastic, so when lit from inside, it gives the appearance of a full moon at night! Using a topology map wouldn't have the same effect because you don't necessarily see the moon's high and low areas from Earth at night, you see the moon's diffuse appearance. I actually got half way through creating this when I realized I needed to use its diffuse color, not topography!
comments.author: JustForFun

description.text:
A friend needed an ODROID XU4 case so I downloaded the STEP-files from here: http://dn.odroid.com/homebackup/ODROID-XU4Cas_SETP.zip

I imported them to 123D Design and exported as STL (medium setting). Then imported to Tinkercad and shaved off the 4 tiny legs on the base and a tiny bit of the "button" on the top, this in order to make them flat for the printing bed.

Printed fine without any supports on my XYZprinting Da Vinici Mini w with the "Excellent" preset.

If you print this you probably want to add some new distances to the base after printing to replace the ones I removed.

title: Replacement part for Skoda Felicia diesel engine : small plastic lever that connects the injection pump to the engine to adjust the fuel injection timing

description.text:
Hi. The model is bulkier than the original lever. I had first designed a copy of the original lever with the same geometry but it was not as robust as the original so I designed a sturdier one by making it bulkier.

It was designed with FreeCAD.

The original lever is 57 mm long, 10 mm wide and 7 mm high.

View from FreeCAD This is the original lever to be replaced. The section at the centre is twisted because I used to hold it in place in the engine with a piece of iron wire that left its mark when the enginie overheated. Side by side, the original lever (viewed upside-down compared to the other photo) in a deteriorated state, a first version of the replacement part (before I red-designed it bulkier) and a standard ballpen (for size reference). View of the engine, under the bonnet. The two red arrows show the 2 balls where the lever connects. It is also possible to see the injection pump and how the accelerator cable connects and actuates the lever. Closer view.

author: tomasjuri

description.text:
Hi!
This object is designed to be used in the boardgame Arcadia Quest, and its expansion Beyond the Grave, to add some atmosphere to the board. It is the fountain and statue built in honor of King David III. I think is placed in the main square in the City of Arcadia, and so, many of the last scenario happen around this place.

I made it in various pieces to make it easier to print. You may want to vary the quality from one piece to other, or even the scale. In any case probably some glue would be needed. Also the statue of King David III can be replaced for any of your beloved heroes or monsters (not King Terror)

In terms of gameplay, you can use this in any scenario that uses the 4A tile, placing it in its central space. This Space is Blocked by default, so no gameplay interruption!

I hope you like and find it funny, and I´ll be glad to read your feedback!

comments.text: This is printing really well, but are you aware that the pillars aren't all level with the printing plane?
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: Same with the tablets. Were they intended to be printed with support material under one end of the inclined side?
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text:
Hi! At first I didn´t notice the wrong leveling on the pillars, since I printed them laying on their side. Some people did tell me about it but almost none had problems with the supports it needs or fails in the prints, so I just keep it that way. If it is a big problem I can change it.
The tablets shouldn´t need any support if printed laying on the print surface.
comments.author: FarrisGoldstein

comments.text: Yeah, I realized that after I made my comment. I've tried to print the pillars on their side twice now, and I don't think I quite have the supports right yet.
